items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 5th December 2021.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Upper Tean river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall this evening. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from tonight into tomorrow, Sunday, 05/12/2021. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into tomorrow 05/12/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Uttoxeter river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall this evening.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected overnight into tomorrow, Sunday 05/12/21.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Picknall Brook, Marchington Brook and Rolleston Brook. . Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into tomorrow 05/12/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer an imminent  threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain, however conditions towards the middle of next week are likely to cause some minor disruption within the harbours along the Dorset Coast.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

River levels have risen at the Hints river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning, 05/12/21.
Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into tomorrow, 06/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Doveridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Sunday, 05/12/21. Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Dove between Rocester and Clay Mills. Further rainfall is forecast today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force. River levels remain high as a result of rainfall and snowmelt over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday, 04/12/2021 and overnight into Sunday, 05/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast and river levels could remain high for a number of days. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Sunday morning 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 03:00 on 05/12/21 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 21 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/12/21, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire coast on Saturday 04/12/2021, between 17:15-18:15 and Sunday 05/12/2021, between 05:30-06:30. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire coast on Saturday 04/12/2021, between 16:45-18:45 and Sunday 05/12/2021, between 05:15-07:00. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: High tides are forecast to bring high levels and large waves along the East Yorkshire coast on Saturday 04/12/2021 and on Sunday, 05/12/2021. The areas most at risk are properties from Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. The highest levels are expected on Saturday afternoon between 16:30-17:00 and Sunday morning, between 04:45-05:15. Our operational staff will be out inspecting our flood defences before and after the peak tides, and we are liaising closely with our partners. Please keep away from flood water. To report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline number 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings. Keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via the Floodline number 0345 988 1188. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: High tides are forecast to bring high levels and large waves along the East Yorkshire coast on Saturday 04/12/2021, between 16:30-17:00 and on Sunday, 05/12/2021 between 04:45-05:15. Please be careful along beaches, coastal  footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Beadnell Harbour Road North and Newbiggin Bay North Promenade as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 02:00 to 05:00 tomorrow morning, 05/12/2021. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Flooding of properties is not expected. The flood gates at Warkworth will not be closed. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The forecast high water is 18:30 on Saturday evening, 04/12/21, with a level of 6.35 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to coastal areas and the most vulnerable properties is possible and may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. High spring tides will continue until Tuesday 07/12/21 and this flood alert may remain in force although the wind strength is forecast to reduce.

Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
The high tides at 11:30 AM and midnight on Sunday 05/12/2021 are not expected to reach flood alert levels. However, forecasts indicate that further alerts/warnings maybe issued from Monday to Wednesday as subsequent high tides coincide with strong winds leading to increased surge.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: While the situation is improving for the weekend, we are expecting a higher tide again on Monday the 6th December 2021. We continue to monitor the situation over the next coming days.

The high tide related to this flood alert has now passed.
We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow's high tides.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

Current levels for the tides Saturday evening and for the morning and evening tide on Sunday are forecasting below the alert threshold. Newport may exceed the flood alert threshold on Monday. An update will be provided on Sunday if this is expected to occur. 
Predicted peaks:
Saturday evening, 4/12/21 - Avonmouth Portbury 7.1 to 7.4m and Newport 6.7 to 7.1m.
 Sunday morning, 5/12/21 – Avonmouth Portbury 7.0 to 7.4m and Newport 6.7 to 7.1m. 

This morning’s tide peaked at 7.51m at Avonmouth and 7.01m at Newport. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as Flooding may affect low lying and roads adjacent to the River Wye.

Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Berwick Between the Bridges as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 02:15 to 04:00 tomorrow morning, 05/12/2021. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Property flooding is not expected.

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Roker Seafront, Hendon Prom and Seaburn Lower Prom as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 02:00 to 06:00 tomorrow morning, 05/12/2021. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Property flooding is not expected. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Due to the unsettled weather affecting the area, tide levels will remain a little elevated over the next few days. The current forecast suggests that further minor impact flooding may occur at high tide (expected at 13:00) on Tuesday 07/12/2021. However, there is a low chance that a developing deep low pressure could change its course and track over southern England which will lead to unusually high surge tides on Tuesday and Wednesday (08/12/2021). If required, we will issue advice on Monday 06/12/2021.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
As a result of spring tides and strong winds, the high tide water level may overtop sea defences in some locations although the flooding of properties is not forecast. The forecast high water is 18:30 on Saturday evening, 04/12/21, with a level of 6.35 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
As a result, the flooding of coastal areas including roads and farmland, is possible at these times and may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas at risk include Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour. This flood alert is unlikely to be reissued during this period of spring tides. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However tide levels on Saturday, Sunday and early next week are forecast to be lower than those experienced Saturday morning (by 20 to 40 cm). Saturday evening's tide at 23:15 on 04/12/2021 will be lower by 0.01 m and is forecast to be 6.02 metres Chart Datum (2.97 mAOD) at Littlehampton. No more than a very small amount of spray is expected to affect Climping seafront. There is the possibility of another low pressure weather system next Tuesday (07/12/2021) and Wednesday (08/12/2021). It is most likely that flood impacts will be no worse than those experienced in recent days. However, there is a very low likelihood of extremely strong winds and large waves, which could affect the beach. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.description: Tidal River Camel excluding Wadebridge and Chapel Amble
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
This message has been updated for Saturday’s high tides. 

Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning and evening. High water at Padstow is at 04:44 and 17:08, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Strong force 7-8 north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. 

Locations particularly at risk include the A389 at Sladesbridge 

Expect tides to be around 200mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.  

This message will be updated on Sunday morning.  There is a possibility that further alerts may be required for Monday morning’s high tide.

items.message:
This message has been updated for Saturday’s high tides. 

Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning and evening. High water at Padstow is at 04:44 and 17:08, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Strong force 7-8 north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Edge of quays likely to flood including any low lying car parks and roads with particular emphasis on Port Quinn, Port Isaac and Port Gaverne, Boscastle and Crooklets Beach 

Expect tides to be around 200mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.  

This message will be updated on Sunday morning.  There is a possibility that further alerts may be required for Monday morning’s high tide.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning and evening. High water at St Ives is at 04:28 and 16:51, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 7 to 8, north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the Causeway at Hayle.
Expect tides to be around 200mm higher than predicted because of forecast weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
This message will be updated on Sunday morning.  There is a possibility that further alerts may be required for Monday morning’s high tide.

Due to the unsettled weather affecting the area, tide levels will remain a little elevated over the next few days. The current forecast suggests that further minor impact flooding may occur at high tide (expected at 12:45) on Tuesday 07/12/2021. However, there is a low chance that a developing deep low pressure could change its course and track over southern England which will lead to unusually high surge tides on Tuesday and Wednesday (08/12/2021). If required, we will issue advice on Monday 06/12/2021.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean
items.message:
The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The forecast high water is 18:30 on Saturday evening, 04/12/21, with a level of 6.35 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding of coastal areas including roads and farmland is possible at these times. However, conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are coastal areas at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean.  Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point and this flood alert is unlikely to be reissued during this period of spring tides. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences. The forecast high water is at 18:30 on Saturday evening, 04/12/21, with a level of 6.35 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level.
Flooding to coastal areas and the most vulnerable properties is possible and may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including properties on the lockside, businesses around the Harbour Masters office, Gibraltar Cottages and other low lying properties on the B3225 at Porlock Weir. High spring tides will continue until Tuesday 07/12/21 but this flood warning is unlikely to be reissued after Saturday as the wind strength is forecast to reduce.

Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels have risen at the Liverpool Road river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Sunday, 05/12/21. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Norton Green and Darlaston including Stoke on Trent, Lyme Brook between Newcastle under Lyme and Hanford, Fowlea Brook at Stoke on Trent and Ford Green Brook. Further rainfall is forecast today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.
